recordings.rmk:
Recorded during the Coronavirus/COVID-19 pandemic as part of permitted exercise. With a huge drop in vehicle movements the general sound of the environment is very different to usual.

Recorded handheld with an Olympus LS-12 and Sennheiser ME66. EQ edited very lightly below 1200 hz to remove very light handling noise and to reduce distant road noise and the sound of the weir at Pultney Bridge which could be heard at over a mile away with so few other sounds in the environment.

recordings.rmk: Recording of normal song of the same adult tame robin whose subdued song is in XC387256 and XC387257.
Recording of normal song of the same adult tame robin whose subdued song is in XC387256 and XC387257.

This is a second recording of an adult tame robin and of what David Lack described as "subdued song", "a puzzling feature of robin singing sometimes heard in autumn", and "audible only at a few yards". I have also submitted separately a sample of its normal song. . The bird is definitely an adult because it became tame  at the start of a 4-5 week period when it was a lone parent feeding a brood of fledglings, some of which also became tame. In the two weeks it has been singing  it sings the subdued song much of the time but it always switches to the normal song if there are other robins around.  The subdued song is sung from the depths of a bush, sometimes very close to the ground,  but the normal song is delivered from a more prominent vantage point.  For comparison I have submitted two recordings of its normal song.  For the two recordings of subdued song the microphone (ME266 LS12 system) was between 40 and 60 cm from the bird. 
Without seeing the robin the subdued song sounds like a robin singing 40-50 metres or more away. However, it sounds completely different  as one gets very close to the bird. The bird does not significantly open its beak during this song, although its chest moves a lot and its tail wags up and down with the singing.  I have been through all the xenocanto recordings of the robin and I think I have  listened to all those that have been designated as subsong.  Most of these are genuine sub song, i.e.\  incomplete song or fragments probably sung by young birds.  I have found  just four recordings so far, in which the recordist gives evidence of the quietness of the song, that can reliably identified as  subdued song.  In XC215370 (Klaus Fink) the bird was not seen singing,  but immediately after the recording the bird emerged from a Taxus bush and sang normal song (XC215371). In XC201447 (Frank Holzapfel) the bird was also not seen but the recordist states that the bird was whispering in the hedge.  In XC44440 and XC44439 (Stuart Fisher) the bird is tame and  it could be seen that the bird was singing quietly.

The recording is of an adult tame robin and is of what David Lack described as "subdued song", "a puzzling feature of robin singing sometimes heard in autumn", and "audible only at a few yards". I have also submitted separately a sample of its normal song. . The bird is definitely an adult because it became tame  at the start of a 4-5 week period when it was a lone parent feeding a brood of fledglings, some of which also became tame. In the two weeks it has been singing  it sings the subdued song much of the time but it always switches to the normal song if there are other robins around.  The subdued song is sung from the depths of a bush, sometimes very close to the ground,  but the normal song is delivered from a more prominent vantage point.  For comparison I have submitted two recordings of its normal song.  For the two recordings of subdued song the microphone (ME266 LS12 system) was between 40 and 60 cm from the bird. 
Without seeing the robin the subdued song sounds like a robin singing 40-50 metres or more away. However, it sounds completely different  as one gets very close to the bird. The bird does not significantly open its beak during this song, although its chest moves a lot and its tail wags up and down with the singing.  I have been through all the xenocanto recordings of the robin and I think I have  listened to all those that have been designated as subsong.  Most of these are genuine sub song, i.e.\  incomplete song or fragments probably sung by young birds.  I have found  just four recordings so far, in which the recordist gives evidence of the quietness of the song, that can reliably identified as  subdued song.  In XC215370 (Klaus Fink) the bird was not seen singing,  but immediately after the recording the bird emerged from a Taxus bush and sang normal song (XC215371). In XC201447 (Frank Holzapfel) the bird was also not seen but the recordist states that the bird was whispering in the hedge.  In XC44440 and XC44439 (Stuart Fisher) the bird is tame and  it could be seen that the bird was singing quietly.
Mixed forest.

recordings.file-name: XC377741-erithacus rubecula (esperanza poveda) castaño del robledo 07-05-2017.mp3
recordings.rmk: El petirrojo es una de las especies dominantes en la zona. Grabado en un bosque serrano de clima casi atlántico, algo raro en estas latitudes, que está constituído principalmente por quejigo y roble melojo además de los castaños cultivados. El sotobosque está formado por helechos además de toda una rica comunidad de matorral mediterráneo.
This is the Robin of my profil photo!
The street gave the Robin's song an amazing natural echo.

4 hours before sunrise. I never heard a Robin at such an early hour. It was sitting in a small tree besides a street-lamp. The same individual also sang in some nights before and after this recording.
very loud and clear

recordings.file-name: XC372965-erithacus rubecula campos de hernán perea 13-04-2017.mp3
recordings.rmk: Tarde con mucho viento en un manantial natural que suministra agua a un abrevadero de ganado. El chorro de agua que surge de la piedra ha labrado un cuenco natural donde beben y se bañan diversas especies de aves. La vegetación circundante consiste en un tupido bosque de chopos, pinos y también pinsapos y cedros, estas dos últimas especies traídas por el icona.

recordings.rmk: On Gran Canaria taxon 'marionae' is proposed. It ought to differ from superbus in winglength and sound. Though not statistically tested, to my ear the song sounds different (more clear?) than the taxon on Tenerife. The song sounds totally different from its European relatives, as it is much more simple and shorter verses.
